channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Former president Joe Biden diagnosed with aggressive form of cancer
item.description: Former President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, which has metastasized to the bone, according to a statement from his personal office.

item.title: After deadly storms, London, Kentucky residents begin recovery
item.description: London, Kentucky is in recovery after deadly tornadoes swept through the small community Friday night.

item.title: What are your favorite director/actor collaborations?
item.description: In this week's installment of Cineplexity, NPR staffers contemplate the best director-actor collaborations in film.

item.title: FBI says primary suspect in Calif. fertility clinic bombing likely died in the blast
item.description: Investigators have identified Guy Edward Bartkus, 25, as the primary suspect in the explosion that injured four others.

item.title: Deadly storms ravage parts of Missouri and Kentucky
item.description: Deadly storms last night caused deaths in Missouri and Kentucky and damaged homes and businesses.

item.title: Unpacking the major developments from President Trump's Middle East trip
item.description: Syria's new leadership has said it wants no trouble with Israel. President Trump has now hinted Syria is willing to go as far as normalizing relations with its once sworn enemy.

item.title: Will the Supreme Court stop nationwide injunctions?
item.description: Supreme Court justices appeared divided on the issue of national injunctions. NPR's Scott Detrow discusses what the Court might do with law professor Nicholas Bagley.

item.title: US suspends health aid to Zambia
item.description: In a dramatic press briefing, a US ambassador sheds tears as he tells the government of Zambia that theft of US donated medicines is forcing him to suspend health aid to the country.

item.title: In Texas, an early heat wave raises concerns for summer
item.description: An early season heat wave is roasting Texas. Spring heat can be particularly dangerous for people's health--here's why.

item.title: From rapid development to trade wars: What it's like to cover China?
item.description: In our latest Reporter's Notebook segment, John Ruwitch discusses what it's like to report on China, which has undergone immense change in the two decades he's been covering it.
